item.description:
2008, China 

“One of the most important films to have emerged from the booming (but still underexplored) field of Chinese independent documentaries” (Dennis Lim, Moving Image Source), Ghost Town is the mesmerizing portrait of Zhiziluo, a remote village in southwest China haunted by traces of its cultural past and barely clinging to life. Tucked away in a rugged corner of Yunnan Province, Lisu and Nu minority villagers squat in the abandoned halls of this remote former communist county seat. A father-son duo of elderly preachers argue over the future of their village church, two young lovers face a break-up over harsh financial realities and a twelve year-old boy, abandoned by his family, scavenges the hillside to feed himself.

“I do not expect to soon find scenes to match Ghost Town’s mountaintop funeral, the running along after a rowdy exorcism, or the scanning of faces at the town Christmas chorale. His back to prosperity, Dayong finds hallowed ground.” –Nick Pinkerton, Village Voice

Divided into three parts, this epic documentary—compared by A.O. Scott of The New York Times to Thomas Hardy’s “intensively observed dramas of rural life, [with their] similar tone of beguiling, melancholy strangeness”—takes an intimate look at its varied cast of characters, bringing audiences face to face with people left behind by China’s new economy. Ghost Town screened as part of the 2010 Flaherty Film Seminar.

 

As this will be a Sunday evening, we will meetup for 'pre-show' dinner at Pho Pasteur (http://phopasteurboston.net/) at 5 pm. 

See you at the Movie,

John
